brief_summary.textblock:
The study hypothesis is that the bioactive compounds of sea buckthorn berries (Hippophaë
      rhamnoides), their fractions, and bilberries (Vaccinium myrtillus). have positive effects on
      lipid and carbohydrate metabolism and will thus reduce the risk of developing metabolic
      diseases.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Berries and Berry Fractions on Metabolic Diseases

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of the project was to investigate whether it is possible to reduce the risk of
      metabolic diseases with supplementing the diet with sea buckthorn berries (Hippophaë
      rhamnoides), their bioactive fractions, and bilberries (Vaccinium myrtillus). The study
      design was a randomized cross-over clinical trial. The participants were slightly and
      moderately overweight female subjects.  In total, 110 female volunteers were recruited, and
      they followed four different berry diets (bilberry, sea buckthorn, sea buckthorn phenolic
      extract and sea buckthorn oil) in a randomized order for 33-35 days. Each intervention was
      followed by a wash-out period  of  30-39  days.  Blood  samples  were drawn  and  physical
      measurements  were performed  after  each  period.  Eighty volunteers completed the study.
      Different markers of lipid and carbohydrate metabolism and inflammation were measured form
      the blood samples.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  BMI 26-34

          -  total cholesterol 4.5-8 mmol/l

          -  LDL chol >2.5 mmol/l

          -  triglycerides <4 mmol/l

          -  glucose <6 mmol/l

          -  insulin <25 mU/l

          -  blood   pressure <160/99 mm Hg

          -  hemoglobin >120 g/l

          -  thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.3-4.2 mU/l

          -  ALAT <60 U/l

          -  creatinine <115 umol/l

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  pregnancy

          -  menopause,

          -  regular smoking

          -  previously diagnosed diabetes (other than gestational)

          -  thyroid, renal, hematological, or hepatic dysfunction

          -  previous  myocardial  infarction

          -  cardiovascular medication

          -  treatment  with  regular medication other than allergy medication or joint lubricates

          -  on-going inflammatory disease

intervention.description: Ethanol-water extract from sea buckthorn berries, combined with maltodextrin, 14.6 g/d (7.3 g sea buckthorn extract + 7.3 g maltodextrin)

facility.name: University of Turku, Dept of Biochemistry and Food Chemistry

clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of the Bioactives of Sea Buckthorn and Bilberry on the Risk of Metabolic Diseases

other_outcome.measure: Subclasses of serum lipoproteins, serum fatty acids and lipid classes of serum
other_outcome.time_frame: Change from beginning to end of each berry treatment (duration of treatments average 33-35 days)

oversight_info.authority: Finland: Ministry of Social Affairs and Health

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from beginnig to end of each berry treatment (duration of treatments average 33-35 days)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

results_reference.citation: Lehtonen HM, Suomela JP, Tahvonen R, Yang B, Venojärvi M, Viikari J, Kallio H. Different berries and berry fractions have various but slightly positive effects on the associated variables of metabolic diseases on overweight and obese women. Eur J Clin Nutr. 2011 Mar;65(3):394-401. doi: 10.1038/ejcn.2010.268. Epub 2011 Jan 12.
